Instead, he seems to be genuinely interested in hearing her opinions and in engaging in conversation with her. However, Hinze's behavior towards Felicia also reveals his tendency to over-interpret and over-value her opinions. When Felicia expresses her opinions on various subjects, Hinze responds with exaggerated praise and admiration, suggesting that he is more interested in impressing her with his own knowledge and sophistication than in genuinely engaging with her thoughts and ideas. Overall, Hinze's interaction with both Tulpian and Felicia reveals his tendency to engage in sycophantic behavior, particularly when interacting with those he considers to be of higher social standing. However, his behavior towards Felicia also suggests that he is capable of genuine interest and engagement, even if this is often overshadowed by his own desire to impress and gain favor.
